BLUEPRINT
Official MCP
Flux is a UI component library designed for Laravel applications using Livewire. It provides a set of pre-built components and styles for building dynamic and interactive web interfaces.

Use Flux when you're building Laravel applications with Livewire and want to leverage a component library specifically designed for the framework. It's suitable for projects that benefit from a consistent design system and tight integration with Livewire's reactive capabilities.

Avoid Flux if you're not using Laravel or Livewire, or if you need a component library that works with other frameworks. Also, consider the dependency on Livewire and the potential impact on your application's performance.

<svg stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" viewBox="0 0 18 13" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <line x1="1" y1="5" x2="1" y2="10"></line>
  <line x1="5" y1="1" x2="5" y2="8"></line>
  <line x1="9" y1="5" x2="9" y2="10"></line>
  <line x1="13" y1="1" x2="13" y2="12"></line>
  <line x1="17" y1="5" x2="17" y2="10"></line>
</svg>
Flux has 35 components, 31 of them are unique – for example profile and avatar are considered as same.
Flux has 2 themes, colors are customizable but either for light or dark themes.
Does not support more than 2 themes at the same time
Imported JavaScript bundle size (minified) of Livewire which is required for Flux
Flux has no JS dependencies but it requires Laravel Livewire.
Flux is not available on NPM but it has 40000 weekly downloads on Packagist
Flux CSS file is not available on CDN
Flux does not use semantic CSS class names. Using semantic and descriptive CSS class names improves readability and maintainability of code independent of the current framework.
Flux requires changing props one by one at build time to do design token customization
Flux does not require a Node.js environment.
Flux does not provide micro CSS files for each component
Flux customizations requires changing props at build time
Flux doesn not use native CSS nesting

daisyUI is a component library for Tailwind CSS that provides pre-designed components with theming capabilities. It is framework-agnostic, meaning it can be used in any web project, and it doesn't ship any JavaScript to the browser.

Use daisyUI when you want to rapidly prototype or build a project with a consistent design system based on Tailwind CSS. It's well-suited for projects where you need a large variety of customizable components and theme options without writing a lot of custom CSS.

Avoid daisyUI if you need highly specific or unique component designs that deviate significantly from the pre-designed styles. Also, if you prefer to build all components from scratch for maximum control over every detail, daisyUI might not be the best choice.
daisyUI is framework agnostic and works everywhere
daisyUI has 63 components, 59 of them are unique – for example pagination and button group are considered as same.
daisyUI supports unlimited themes at the same time, allowing for dynamic theme switching.
daisyUI doesn't ship JavaScript to browsers
daisyUI has no dependencies. It's immune to 3rd party vulnerabilities, dependency version mismatch, and deprecation issues.
In GitHub's top 400 repositories of all time
daisyUI CSS file is available on CDN
daisyUI uses semantic CSS class names. Using semantic and descriptive CSS class names improves readability and maintainability of code independent of the current framework.
daisyUI provides tokens, root-level CSS variables and component-level CSS variables that let you adjust colors, sizes, spacing, radius, and other styles to match your design.
daisyUI can be used as a standalone file, with Tailwind CSS standalone version. This is useful for projects without a Node.js environment.
daisyUI provides micro CSS files for each component
daisyUI uses CSS variables for design customization at runtime
daisyUI uses native CSS nesting, reducing the CSS file size
Tasks that might be easier with daisyUI compared to Flux

Developers often use stars to bookmark projects. More developers have chosen to star daisyUI over Flux on GitHub. Flux offers a good selection of components. daisyUI offers a wider selection compared to Flux. daisyUI runs as a self-contained plugin for Tailwind CSS
Flux offers a good selection of components. daisyUI offers a wider selection compared to Flux.
daisyUI's architecture is built around runtime theming using CSS variables. Flux usually relies on build-time theme generation.
Developers often use stars to bookmark projects. More developers have chosen to star daisyUI over Flux on GitHub. Many projects rely on daisyUI, as shown by its substantial download numbers
Developers often use stars to bookmark projects. More developers have chosen to star daisyUI over Flux on GitHub.
Many projects rely on daisyUI, as shown by its substantial download numbers.
daisyUI runs as a self-contained plugin for Tailwind CSS.
daisyUI adds components to Tailwind CSS with a philosophy centered on CSS. This contrasts with Flux, which often integrates more deeply with JavaScript frameworks.
